tutorials.title: FX3 / FX30 / FX2 – Time of Day Timecode Setup

steps.content:
Press [MENU] > [Shooting] > [7 TC/UB]

Time Code Run – Free Run
Time Code Preset – Set this to the current time of day (second accurate is sufficient)
Time Code Make – Preset
User Bit Time Rec – Off

Press [MENU] > [Setup] > [7 Display Option]

TC/UB Disp. Setting – TC

That's it – you're ready.

The timecode runs independently from recording and keeps running even when the camera is powered off. Always double-check the timecode before starting a new shooting day.

tutorials.title: FX6 / FX9 – Time of Day Timecode Setup (Internal or External)

steps.content:
Connect a timecode sync device (Tentacle, Deity, etc.) to the TC IN port.
Set the sync device to Time of Day and jam the camera. Skip step if you don't have a sync device.

Press [MENU] > [TC/Media] > [Timecode]

Mode – Preset
Run – Free Run
Source – Internal (if no external device is connected)

(manual setup without sync device)
Press [TC Preset]
Set the current time of day (second accurate is sufficient)

Press [MENU] > [Monitoring] > [Display Output]

TC Display – On

That's it – you're ready.

The timecode runs independently from recording and keeps running even when the camera is powered off. Always double-check the timecode before starting a new shooting day.

tutorials.title: VENICE / VENICE 2 – Time of Day Timecode Setup

steps.content:
Connect a professional timecode sync device to the TC IN port.
Set the device to Time of Day and jam the camera. Skip step if you don't have a sync device.

Press [MENU] > [TC/Media] > [Timecode]

Mode – Preset
Run – Free Run
TC Source – External (when jammed) or Internal

(manual setup if no sync device is used)
Select [TC Preset]
Set the current time of day (second accurate is sufficient)

Press [MENU] > [Monitoring] > [Status Display]

Timecode Display – On

That's it – you're ready.

The timecode runs independently from recording and keeps running even when the camera is powered off. Always double-check the timecode before starting a new shooting day.

tutorials.title: A7S III – Time of Day Timecode Setup

steps.content:
Press [MENU] > [Shooting] > [TC/UB]

Time Code Run – Free Run
Time Code Preset – Set to current time of day
Time Code Make – Preset
User Bit – Off

Press [MENU] > [Setup] > [Display Option]

TC/UB Disp. Setting – TC

That's it – you're ready.

The timecode runs independently from recording and keeps running even when the camera is powered off. Always double-check the timecode before starting a new shooting day.

tutorials.title: A7 IV / A6700 – Time of Day Timecode Setup (Limitations)

steps.content:
Press [MENU] > [Shooting] > [TC/UB]

Time Code Make – Preset
Time Code Run – Free Run
Time Code Preset – Set to current time of day

Press [MENU] > [Setup] > [Display Option]

TC Display – On

That's it – you're ready.

The timecode runs independently from recording and keeps running even when the camera is powered off. Always double-check the timecode before starting a new shooting day.

tutorials.title: FR7 – Time of Day Timecode Setup

steps.content:
Connect a timecode sync device to the TC IN port.
Set the device to Time of Day and jam the camera.
Skip step if you don't have a sync device.

Press [MENU] > [TC/Media] > [Timecode]

Mode – Preset
Run – Free Run
Source – External (when jammed) or Internal

Manual sync without a sync device:
Select [TC Preset]
Set the current time of day manually

Press [MENU] > [Monitoring] > [Display]

Timecode Display – On

That's it – you're ready.

Always confirm timecode after remote power-on or reboot.
If you don't have a camera yet or your camera isn't listed, here are your options:

Option 1: Time of Day Setup

Google how to set your camera's timecode to the current time of day.

Most professional cameras support this feature in their menu system. Search for:
"[Your camera model] timecode setup"

Option 2: Use Rec Run Mode

You can use Marker without timecode by choosing Rec Run mode:

1. Start recording on your camera
2. Start the Marker session at the same time

This works great for:
• Long video clips
• Video podcasts
• Long interviews
• Live streams

Not ideal for:
• Shoots with many short clips
• B-Roll sessions
• Multi-camera setups with frequent stops

You're ready!

Choose the workflow that fits your shooting style and start marking your best moments! You can always go back to the tutorial in settings.
No worries. Marker works with every camera.

How syncing works

In video production, files contain metadata like frame rate, resolution and timecode.

Marker also uses timecode to place your markers perfectly synced to your footage.

To make this work, you only need to set your camera's timecode to the current time of day.

You don't need any external sync device.
It's enough to manually set the timecode to the current clock time as precisely as possible.

Once your camera records the correct timecode, Marker can sync perfectly with your footage.

If your camera isn't listed in our database yet, feel free to research online or in your camera's manual how to set up timecode.

Using Marker without timecode

If you can't find a timecode setting on your camera, you can still use Marker in Rec Run mode.

Just start recording on your camera and start the Marker session at the same time.

This works great for long continuous recordings like video podcasts, interviews or events.

It's not ideal for shoots with many short clips, because you would need to start a new Marker session for every clip.

If possible, Time of Day timecode is always the recommended option.

Help make Marker even better

Education is a big part for Marker for Creators. I'm building Marker as a solo developer and I'm adding tutorials for more and more cameras over time.

If your camera isn't listed yet and you know how to set up timecode on it, I'd love your help.

You can send me your camera model and the setup steps, and I'll add it so everyone can use it (you might also get a lil thank you reward as well ^^)

Thanks for helping make Marker for Creators the best live marker app out there!
